question.body: Which of the following does not describe a pleural effusion with transudate fluid?

multiple_choice.choice: A venous blockade increases hydrostatic pressure.
Have a significant increase in protein.
Have a normal cell count and distribution.

response.feedback: Incorrect. A venous blockade can increase hydrostatic pressure resulting in a pleural effusion which is a buildup of excess fluid that can impede lung expansion. This fluid appears normal, the blockage just prevents proper drainage.

Incorrect. If the lymphatic system is not able to drain the excess fluid the fluid can then build up creating a pleural effusion which can impede lung expansion. This fluid is transudate fluid because it is normal in appearance.
Correct. A significant increase in protein usually indicates infection which would cause the fluid to be gray or cloudy and to be classified as exudates.

Incorrect. Transudate fluid is the result of impaired drainage of the lungs that results in a pleural effusion. This buildup of fluid is normal in appearance and does not have a higher protein or cell count.
